page.section: The implementation of the Disability Discrimination Act, and its requirement that employers must make reasonable adjustments to enable disabled employees to attain to their full potential in the workplace, has made a major impact in recent years. Many employers now have a good understanding of the needs of a wide range of disabled people, and what they need to do to meet those needs.

However, understanding of the needs of people on the autistic spectrum, including those with Asperger syndrome (AS), is far less widespread. The fact is that people on the spectrum are hard-wired to interact differently in social situations, and problems can arise if the people around them - purely through ignorance or unfamiliarity - react badly to their non-standard behaviours.

Now, a short book has been written which helps to avoid this. The clear and simple illustrations show colleagues how the world can appear to the employee with AS, and demonstrate how small changes in approach can transform workplace relationships. The book gives colleagues a range of strategies to bridge the gap between the two perspectives; and in doing so, it will make the workplace a richer and more productive environment for everybody.
For example, you can intuitively 'read' people, but we can't easily tell what mood you're in - like whether you're upset or happy...
img/p2.png
...which can make us seem insensitive. Some people even assume we are annoyed with them!
We can't easily tell if you are bored, tired, or embarrassed...
img/p3.png
and so we might keep on talking when you think we should stop.
We don't 'register' the 'rules' of conversation
img/p4.png
...so we might interrupt, or break the flow, or introduce topics out of place.
Aspers don't 'see' these 'rules' of conversation - and can't learn them like you do. We forever guess!
img/p5.png
But some of us work out other ways to get by. Like sets of rules with our own special logic.
Sometimes these behaviours don't really bother other people. Sometimes they do...
img/p6.png
...especially if people think we are being deliberately rude or thoughtless.
But Aspers are effectively born unable to see social nuances intuitively - whatever other skills or gifts we have.
img/p7.png
We may come up with complex ways to 'get by' in social interactions, but we are often forced to just 'wing it' - sometimes several times each conversation!
For example, we may have to guess which tone and body language to use when we're speaking.
img/p8.png
...and if we get it wrong we could sound arrogant or condescending or cold hearted... and not know it.
We don't easily know when to smile, or laugh, or offer sympathy; it may look artificial when we try. We won't know if your story is meant to be sad or funny.
img/p9.png
We often automatically look away when talking or listening. Some don't make eye contact at all. Others stare constantly.

Thanks for reading this.

We hope it helps you and your colleague to work better together in the long run. You may have to re-evaluate how you view them; you might have formed wrong impressions already.

Remember: they won't mind directness. So ask them anything that is on your mind about this. They'd really prefer it!

We know some people don't like being direct; maybe they could send a note now and again.

And some people won't enjoy working with others regardless - we know that. But since we can't 'take a hint' you'll have to tell us if you expect us to know!

If you can, please:
- Be DIRECT with us - CHECK what we really mean - DON'T be embarrassed: enjoy our differences!
